abstract.para: This glossary tries to provide an overview of the terms used in MMBase and their meaning. As MMBase has evolved during the last years, its language evolved with it. This means that sometimes one term refers to two concepts, whereas in other occasions two terms are synonyms for one and the same thing. Therefore this document tries to describe the meaning of the terms used in MMBase in the different contexts. Next to this, the glossary tries to provide a list preferred terms.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Below you see how a term is explained in this glossary. First an example of the term MMBase is given and then the different elements in the definition of a term are described.

listitem.para: for managers: open source content management system, with strong multi-media features
for dummies: a tool by which you can build intelligent websites

glossdef.para: MMBase objects are generally referred to as 'node'. A normal MMBase node corresponds to one record in the database (in the table(s) associated with the builder). We recognize also 'cluster nodes' and 'virtual nodes'.

Complicated database queries do not give back simple nodes, but fields from several tables. A record from such a table join is represented by a 'cluster node'. A cluster node is a special kind of virtual node.
A node to which no builder xml is associated.

listitem.para: A bunch of interrelated nodes viewed as a unity.
All nodes from one MMBase instance.
All nodes inside an MMBase transaction.

glossdef.para: The bridge are the Java interfaces which are to be used to talk to MMBase. In contradiction to the core of MMBase all actions are authorized by the security system. Templating language should communicate through the bridge, and for example the MMBase Taglib is doing thing.
There is currently one 'basic' implementation of the bridge, and also one alternative implementation which makes it possible to talk to a 'remote' MMBase by remote method invocations.
An alternative to the bridge. Can be used to implement life/staging MMBase's, but can also be useful to inspect/test a running MMBase.
A packaged content managment system based on MMBase. Typical for WIAB is a fixed object model and a distinction between life and staging environments. It was developed for the Amsterdam municipal.
High status MMBase commitors who meet every thursday to talk about it.
An XML way to add content to an MMBase cloud.
A way to synchronize data from another source with MMBase data. This happens in a fuzzy way, to avoid duplications because of minor inconsistencies in the source data.

listitem.para: In several security implementation the concept 'security context' is stored in the owner field, to attribute rights to objects.
In a J2EE environment the web-application is associated with a 'context', which is basicly the first parth of the path. Often it will be '/', but this is not required for MMBase.
In MMBase taglib a 'context' is a container for Taglib variables. It is also asociated with every page, the 'context' tag, and list tags.

glossdef.para: A value for the 'dir' attribute of reldef and insrel nodes. It only sais something about the visibility of the relation. A unidirection relation is not visible from the destination node.

A value for the 'dir' attribute of reldef and insrel nodes. It only sais something about the visibility of the relation. Every MMBase relation is bidirection in the sense that it has a clearly defined source and destination.
A Tag Library is a SUN defined way to define extra XML-like tags. A tag libraray is implemented in Java and currently only available in mixture with JSP-pages.
A taglib implementation for MMBase. Tags to access MMBase data, but also more general tags. It consists more or less a complete (however simple) language.
